definition[0]: an alphabetical list of names, subjects etc at the back of a book, with the numbers of the pages where they can be found
definition[1]: a set of cards or a database containing information, usually arranged in alphabetical order and used especially in a library
definition[2]: a standard by which the level of something can be judged or measured
example[0]: The changing size of an infant’s head is considered an index of brain growth.
definition[3]: a system by which prices, costs etc can be compared to those of a previous date
definition[4]: if documents, information etc are indexed, an index is made for them
example[1]: The reports are indexed by subject and location.
definition[5]: to arrange for the level of wages, pensions etc to increase or decrease according to the level of prices
example[2]: demands that wages be indexed to the rise in prices
definition[6]: something such as a price, amount, level etc that shows the general level of related prices etc
example[4]: The price of gold bullion on the exchange remains a sensitive index of confidence in the international market.
definition[7]: a figure showing the level of something, for example prices, in relation to earlier levels. Indexes often use the figure 100 as the BASE in a particular year and figures for later years are given in relation to this base
definition[8]: an official list of the average price of shares in a group of companies on a particular stockmarket
example[5]: Milan’s Stock Index fell 2% in the year.
definition[9]: to arrange for the level of payments such as wages or PENSIONs to go up at the same rate as something else, usually prices
example[7]: Tax exemptions should be indexed to the purchasing power of the pound.
definition[10]: if an investment is indexed to something, for example a currency or a STOCK INDEX,  its value rises and falls in relation to the currency etc
example[8]: The yield of Ukrainian treasury bills is indexed to the value of the local currency, the hryvnia, in terms of the dollar.
